item.title: Help please
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

Pwnd, you had a bracket too much. Here:

[code] //
/ Spankjavas /
/ /
//
import java.awt.;
import java.awt.event.;
import javax.swing.*;
/**

  • Summary description for Spankjavas

*/
public class Spankjavas extends JFrame implements ActionListener
{
// Variables declaration
private JTextField jTextField2;
private JButton jButton1;
private JButton jButton2;
private JButton jButton3;
private JButton jButton4;
// End of variables declaration

public Spankjavas()
{
	//super();
	initializeComponent();
	//
	// TODO: Add any constructor code after initializeComponent call
	//

	this.setVisible(true);
}

/**
 * This method is called from within the constructor to initialize the form.
 * WARNING: Do NOT modify this code. The content of this method is always regenerated
 * by the Windows Form Designer. Otherwise, retrieving design might not work properly.
 * Tip: If you must revise this method, please backup this GUI file for JFrameBuilder
 * to retrieve your design properly in future, before revising this method.
 */
private void initializeComponent()
{
	jTextField2 = new JTextField();
	jButton1 = new JButton("Up");
	jButton2 = new JButton("Right");
	jButton3 = new JButton("Left");
	jButton4 = new JButton("Down");
	jButton1.addActionListener(this);
	jButton2.addActionListener(this);
	jButton3.addActionListener(this);
	jButton4.addActionListener(this);
	JPanel panel = new JPanel();

	//
	// contentPane
	//
	panel.setLayout(null);
	//panel.setBorder(BorderFactory.createRaisedBevelBorder());
	addComponent(panel, jTextField2, 5,34,324,72);
	addComponent(panel, jButton1, 84,2,83,28);
	addComponent(panel, jButton2, 257,2,83,28);
	addComponent(panel, jButton3, 3,1,83,28);
	addComponent(panel, jButton4, 171,1,83,28);
	//
	// Spankjavas
	//
	this.setTitle("Spankjavas -  Noobthing");
	this.setLocation(new Point(10, 3));
	this.setSize(new Dimension(349, 149));
}

/** Add Component Without a Layout Manager (Absolute Positioning) */
private void addComponent(Container container,Component c,int x,int y,int width,int height)
{
	c.setBounds(x,y,width,height);
	container.add(c);
}

//
// TODO: Add any appropriate code in the following Event Handling Methods
//

public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent ae) {
	String cmd = ae.getActionCommand();
	System.out.println(cmd + " called!");
	/*if (cmd.equals("Up")) {
	} else if (cmd.equals("Left")) {
	} else if (cmd.equals("Right")) {
	} else if (cmd.equals("Down")) {
	} else  System.out.println("Unkown action: " + cmd);*/

}

public static void main(String[] args) {
	new Spankjavas();
}

}

//============================= Testing ================================//
//= =//
//= The following main method is just for testing this class you built.=//
//= After testing,you may simply delete it. =//
//======================================================================//
public static void main(String[] args)
{
JFrame.setDefaultLookAndFeelDecorated(true);
JDialog.setDefaultLookAndFeelDecorated(true);
try
{
UIManager.setLookAndFeel(“com.sun.java.swing.plaf.windows.WindowsLookAndFeel”);
}
catch (Exception ex)
{
System.out.println("Failed loading L&F: ");
System.out.println(ex);
}
new Spankjavas();
}
//= End of Testing =
[/code]

besides, you have no class defined

item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[code] //
/ Spankjavas /
/ /
//
import java.awt.;
import java.awt.event.;
import javax.swing.*;
/**

  • Summary description for Spankjavas

*/
public class Spankjavas extends JFrame implements ActionListener
{
// Variables declaration
private JTextField jTextField2;
private JButton jButton1;
private JButton jButton2;
private JButton jButton3;
private JButton jButton4;
// End of variables declaration

public Spankjavas()
{
	//super();
	initializeComponent();
	//
	// TODO: Add any constructor code after initializeComponent call
	//

	this.setVisible(true);
}

/**
 * This method is called from within the constructor to initialize the form.
 * WARNING: Do NOT modify this code. The content of this method is always regenerated
 * by the Windows Form Designer. Otherwise, retrieving design might not work properly.
 * Tip: If you must revise this method, please backup this GUI file for JFrameBuilder
 * to retrieve your design properly in future, before revising this method.
 */
private void initializeComponent()
{
	jTextField2 = new JTextField();
	jButton1 = new JButton("Up");
	jButton2 = new JButton("Right");
	jButton3 = new JButton("Left");
	jButton4 = new JButton("Down");
	jButton1.addActionListener(this);
	jButton2.addActionListener(this);
	jButton3.addActionListener(this);
	jButton4.addActionListener(this);
	JPanel panel = new JPanel();

	//
	// contentPane
	//
	panel.setLayout(null);
	//panel.setBorder(BorderFactory.createRaisedBevelBorder());
	addComponent(panel, jTextField2, 5,34,324,72);
	addComponent(panel, jButton1, 84,2,83,28);
	addComponent(panel, jButton2, 257,2,83,28);
	addComponent(panel, jButton3, 3,1,83,28);
	addComponent(panel, jButton4, 171,1,83,28);
	//
	// Spankjavas
	//
	this.setTitle("Spankjavas -  Noobthing");
	this.setLocation(new Point(10, 3));
	this.setSize(new Dimension(349, 149));
}

/** Add Component Without a Layout Manager (Absolute Positioning) */
private void addComponent(Container container,Component c,int x,int y,int width,int height)
{
	c.setBounds(x,y,width,height);
	container.add(c);
}

//
// TODO: Add any appropriate code in the following Event Handling Methods
//

public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent ae) {
	String cmd = ae.getActionCommand();
	System.out.println(cmd + " called!");
	/*if (cmd.equals("Up")) {
	} else if (cmd.equals("Left")) {
	} else if (cmd.equals("Right")) {
	} else if (cmd.equals("Down")) {
	} else  System.out.println("Unkown action: " + cmd);*/

}

public static void main(String[] args) {
	new Spankjavas();
}

}

//============================= Testing ================================//
//= =//
//= The following main method is just for testing this class you built.=//
//= After testing,you may simply delete it. =//
//======================================================================//
public static void main(String[] args)
{
JFrame.setDefaultLookAndFeelDecorated(true);
JDialog.setDefaultLookAndFeelDecorated(true);
try
{
UIManager.setLookAndFeel(“com.sun.java.swing.plaf.windows.WindowsLookAndFeel”);
}
catch (Exception ex)
{
System.out.println("Failed loading L&F: ");
System.out.println(ex);
}
new Spankjavas();
}
//= End of Testing =

}

[/code]
I revised it, but I get some scary ass error that makes completely no sense.
Perhaps Uriko has hax

Spankjavas.java:135: class, interface, or enum expected public static void main(String[] args) ^ Spankjavas.java:138: class, interface, or enum expected JDialog.setDefaultLookAndFeelDecorated(true ^ Spankjavas.java:139: class, interface, or enum expected try ^ Spankjavas.java:142: class, interface, or enum expected } ^ Spankjavas.java:146: class, interface, or enum expected System.out.println(ex); ^ Spankjavas.java:147: class, interface, or enum expected } ^ Spankjavas.java:149: class, interface, or enum expected } ^

item.title: Help please
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Okie dokie.

So, you make your button in a class that implements ActionListener. Do, buttonVarName.addActionListener(this);.

Then, you must add this method:

public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent ae) { }

If that button is the only thing you have registered to listen event for, do this:

public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent ae) { textField.setText("WHATEVERTEXT HEER"); }

If you want to make sure that it is the button being pressed:

public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent ae) { String cmd = ae.getActionCommand(); if (cmd.equals("BUTTON TEXT")) { textField.setText("WHATEVERTEXT HEER"); } else System.out.println("Idk what just happened"); }

I hope that helped :]

Read full topic
